com.github.funler.widget_android

Class WidgetView

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.funler.widget_android.WidgetView

  • public class WidgetView
extends java.lang.Object
    This is the main class which incapsulates all logic (opening/closing activity etc) and provides high-level methods to manipulate with.

    Almost all methods of this class supports "method chaining".

    All you need to start working with the class is to instantiate WidgetView once and initialize it with few required params. Example: 

             
              List<String> sections = new ArrayList<>();
              sections.add("YOUR_SECTION_1");
              sections.add("YOUR_SECTION_2");
              sections.add("YOUR_SECTION_3");

              WidgetView widgetView = new WidgetView(context);
              widgetView.init("YOUR_APP_ID", sections);

    Parameter `sections` depends on your RMS configuration. If you use `default` placement for rewards you can omit this parameter.

             
              WidgetView widgetView = new WidgetView(context);
              widgetView.init("YOUR_APP_ID");

    That's enough for start loading WidgetView, but note that WidgetView still remains hidden. Also, first load of WidgetView takes a some time which depends on network connection quality. That's why you need to init WidgetView as soon as possible. Next initializations after opening app again will be faster because of caching.

    If you want to show WidgetView right after it has initialized, you can add listener WidgetView.OnInitializationHandler implementation which will invoke method show on WidgetView instance. Example: 

             
              widgetView.onInitializationFinished(hasItems -> {
                  widgetView.show(); // we can show widget without checking is it has rewards configured in RMS
              });
         
     

             
              widgetView.onInitializationFinished(hasItems -> {
                  if (hasItems) { // we can show empty widget if it has no rewards configured in RMS
                      widgetView.show();
                  }
              });

    But the most common way is assigning OnClickListener to some View. Example:

             
              button.setOnClickListener(view -> {
                  widgetView.show();
              });

    See Also:
    WidgetView.OnSignInHandler, WidgetView.OnSignUpHandler, WidgetView.OnGetClaimedRewardsHandler, WidgetView.OnGetUserByEmailHandler, WidgetView.OnInitializationHandler

      • sendDataToField

        public WidgetView sendDataToField(java.lang.String fieldName,
                                  java.lang.String value)
        Sends data to WidgetView field on SignUp/SignIn pages. For example, you know user email and don't want to let user enter his email again. So, you can do that for user by invoking this method.
        Parameters:
        fieldName - The field name you want to populate. Examples: "email", "password".
        value - The field value.
        Returns:
        current instance of WidgetView.

      • setMode

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        current instance of WidgetView.
